channel.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help
channel.description:
EDIT :
Something is SPECIFICALLY blocking port 43594.
I just checked about 100 random port numbers, and each of them were open.
The only port number which is blocked is 43594, TCP.
UDP is open, it's just TCP.
Oh my god, help this is so fustrating LOL

item.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help
item.dc:creator: @Sp3ke Sp3ke
item.description:
@Sp3ke wrote:

Ok yes it’s the ports.

For some reason they are ALL blocked apart from 43594 UDP.

Have you any reason why this is the only one unblocked? Heres a screenshot

Read full topic

@_Rich wrote:

Check his client again to make sure, also make sure the no-ip duc is running, and look to see if you’ve correctly port forwarded.

item.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help
item.dc:creator: @Sp3ke Sp3ke
item.description:
@Sp3ke wrote:

But my problem is that they cant connect. I just tested it with a friend and he gets an error connecting to server.

I’ve set his client to run of the no-ip server, and my own client to run off 127.0.0.1, but only I seem to be able to log in/

Read full topic

item.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help

@_Rich wrote:

The no-ip is there so others can connect, it’s fine.

item.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help
item.dc:creator: @Sp3ke Sp3ke
item.description:
@Sp3ke wrote:

UPDATE :

I’m running the client off my computer from 127.0.0.1,

I’ve duped the client which runs off my no-ip for other users.

I’ve linked the client to a friend and he gets error connecting to server…

43594 is open, my no-ip is running, he has the full client

Any suggestions?

Read full topic

item.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Yes, you have to connect to your server, on your computer, with the IP of 127.0.0.1, However, Other people that want to connect have to use your No-IP address. So the client your using, on the same computer your server is hosted from, has to connect with 127.0.0.1, while everyone else has to do servername.no-ip.org or whatever you have.

Read full topic

item.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help
item.dc:creator: @Sp3ke Sp3ke
item.description:
@Sp3ke wrote:

Thanks for the super fast reply.

Let me recap though, so what you’re saying is I have to put the IP address as “127.0.0.1”?

But surley putting it as that will mean other people cant connect?

Sorry for being dumb,

thanks again,

Sp3ke

Read full topic

item.title: Oh Em Gee - Portforwarding help
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Okay, here is a common problem people have with No-IP. If YOU are hosting the server on YOUR computer, you HAVE to use the localhost address(127.0.0.1). Here’s an easy illustration:

Your server hosted on your computer, and connecting to it on your computer -> IP: 127.0.0.1
Your server hosted on your computer, and connecting to it on a different computer -> IP: yourservername.no-ip.org

  1. The main difference between 317’s and 508’s(I think that’s what you were getting at) is the content, and the mapdata, and the graphics.
  2. The port your server is running on is usually said when you start your server, and is usually 43594, or 43595. If not, just look in server.java, or SocketListener, or ConnectionManager, for “port”

Hope I helped a bit.

Read full topic
